content: episode 19 catacomb entrance hey guys welcome back to another episode of black
magic crafts today I'm going to show you how I built this cool-looking catacomb
entrance it is a relatively easy and quick little Styrofoam project to build
but it looks really cool on your game table I'm going to be using it in my D&D
game but it would work well in frost graves in war gaming and any other kind
of RPG as it is a pretty generic looking piece so let's take a look at how I
built it and then you can make your own so this is my catacomb entrance now when
I made this it was for an encounter that my players as of the time of recording
this video will be doing in a few days it'll start out in the cemetery using
the chapel from the previous episode but I wanted a entrance to the actual
dungeon a way for them to get below ground and into the catacombs and I
didn't want that entrance to be within the chapel I wanted it to be within the
cemetery itself so I needed a catacomb entrance and this created a bit of a
problem in terms of what to build because I wanted something that was
freestanding in the cemetery with doors that would lead to a lower level my
first thought was to do something that was embedded in a hill kind of like a
hobbit house that was a doorway in stone leading below I think that would have
looked cool but I think that it would have been one bigger than I wanted once
you have a hill that would conceal the door and then would only be able to be
used in the kind of grassy terrain to match whatever I did hill with I wanted
something that I could drop into other places with this for example you know
it's meant to go outside just in the landscape and be an entrance but if I
really wanted to I could put this indoors into the dungeon you know
leading down to a lower level you know it's a freestanding object so I was
thinking how do I how do I accomplish this I didn't really
want to build a full building like I looking into catacomb entrance photos
online I saw a lot of them were basically little buildings that you go
into and then you know you descend but didn't want to have a full other
building so I kind of had the thought of doing it
similar to a lot of modern-day utility entrances where there's just a little
building with a sloped roof to accommodate going down into a stairwell
and I'm pretty happy with that compromise I think it works well it
keeps the piece reasonably small it kept it simple to build and I think it looks
pretty cool and it's kind of obvious as to what it is if you put this you know a
grasp board in a cemetery you can tell that obviously this is leading to a
stairwell to a lower surface so in order to achieve this I used very similar
methods to previous builds where there is a sub structure and it's faced with
different layers of brick so this one I started by making this
kind of triangle wedge shape and I achieve this by layering two layers of
inch-and-a-half insulation foam gluing them together
letting it dry and then cutting out this wedge shape once I had that and I was
happy with the shape I went ahead and I made a door which is just you know a
thin layer of the insulation foam with the wood pallets or wood planks you know
drawn in with a pen the wood grain is done with the wire brush I then took
some little strips of wood for these kind of braces here glued those on use
the pin to indent little holes to imply some kind of nails once I had the door
on there I went did these bricks around it that kind of
frame the doorways archway that's when this thing kind of started to take shape
and I knew that I was on the right track so at that point I went and I made a
whole bunch of individual friction to glue to the side these are I think
they're 1 centimeter by 2 centimeters about I can't remember I might have just
free handed like picked a size kind of what eyeball looked good we'll just save
1 by 2 centimeters but these ones I sliced very thin so that I could when
facing it wrap them around this curve and just glued them all on with kylene's
aliens whatever it's called tacky glue same as I always do again I love this
technique I think it adds so much depth to a piece from now on I think I'm
building basically everything like that once
I had those sides on I wanted this to kind of match aesthetically the
cathedral or chapel from that previous video so I did these side buttresses
just to kind of decorate it I did them exact same as I did on the chapel which
is just cutting a basically a square piece of insulation foam and then
itching in the bricks with a pencil or pen I glued those to the side and then I
needed something to do for the quote-unquote roof this and I just cut
up some more bricks but these ones I made thicker so that they're more like
this scale actual size that they should be on the piece and starting from the
bottom and actually start from the bottom my camera no I think I started
from the top and worked my way down so that whatever I ended up here at the
bottom could just be sliced afterwards I used a mix of different colors of bricks
one because I was just using scrap material and also I was hoping that the
different colors of styrofoam would kind of bleed through in my paint job to give
it some variants but when I got to painting I ended up coating this pretty
heavily in the base coat and the color of the styrofoam didn't end up
showing through so it was kind of irrelevant when I when I did the side
bricks I just let them all over hang like runs wild and then once it was dry
before doing this roof I just followed the edge of the roof and sliced them off
and it was kind of the same thing with the with the roof bricks line up on one
edge and I just kind of ran them wild as I was finishing them and then once it
was dried I kind of went around and cut the edges off if I'm not when possible
is easier to do than cutting the little bricks to lengths first if you can just
run them wild and I cut them off afterwards it'll make things a lot
easier it's the same with the bottom when I got to this bottom edge you can
see that there is a bevel on this one these I just ran them long and then once
the glue is nice and tacked up and dry I could just take my knife and cut it
flush which gave me the right angle on these so that it would sit nice and flat
on the ground once I had those done I was happy with the way it looked but I
thought it needed some kind of embellishment so I added this decoration
to the front of it this is just a piece of the ready board the dollar store foam
core that I cut to shape I took a skull bead that was from Halloween bracelet
two years ago I put that in place the nice thing is that it hurt he came with
a hole drilled right through it because it's a bead and then I used some
toothpicks that went through the star through the ready board into the skull
and then down into the piece it was really really strong it was a little
tricky to get these toothpicks going straight down through this thin piece of
foam core without breaking it but I just took my time did it slowly and managed
to not explode it there's a little bit of itching on here for some more
decoration but that was basically it once that was all done I tried an
experiment for foam coating you don't normally do the Mod Podge but I've heard
a few people taking drywall joint compound and really watering it down
mixing it with some glue and then coating a whole piece in that
and I tried that out and it did make the piece fairly hard it also made the piece
nice and flat which would accept paint really well because the drywall compound
is is is very flat and porous but I found that it did remove a lot more
detail than I then I would have liked there was a lot of fine detail in this I
don't know that was kind of obscured by that some of it still showing through
with these cracks like some of these bricks I individually sliced when I was
putting them on to show cracking and it hasn't come through as strongly as I
think it would have with the Mod Podge whatever it was an experiment I think
it's a great technique if you're doing stuff like Hills whatever but a fine
detail work I'll probably stick to just a layer of Mod Podge which I then
decided to put on top as well just to see how strong something would be with
both the joint compound and the Mod Podge and I have to say it's pretty
pretty hard most of the stuff I make is to hold up to home DND games with my
group of friends who you know respect the stuff that's on the table and I
don't transport it so I don't worry too much but for people that are doing stuff
at like your local game store or doing more war gaming where things can get
abused I would say this would absolutely hold up to any of that kind of abuse so
it is a good system to make styrofoam really hard and protected after the Mod
Podge went to paint and I think I coated the whole thing in kind of a tan with
the exception of the the doors and I did a little bit coloring with washes this
time I didn't do too much actual paint work I did a black wash did some lighter
dry brushing and then a whole bunch of washes after that I had this idea that
it'd be nice to get the washes onto the piece without a brush so that you don't
get any brush lines or splotches I kind of wanted to let the liquid just fall on
it and let gravity do its job and an airbrush is like obviously the best way
to do that but I don't have an airbrush and while it's something I will be
getting at some point I wasn't about to get it right away so I just used those
these cheap like three for a dollar squirt bottles from the dollar store put
my wash in there squirted it on I mean it ain't pretty but it gets everything
covered and coded without any brush marks it actually gives them a splatter
effects if you want that which I did do near the end I did some green washes
it's probably hard to see but there is like green undertones in here because I
wanted it to look very like it's got a lot of like recalling lost not moss but
just mold moss whatever and outside for a long time sitting in water but anyway
the spray bottle allowed me to put that on in a nice kind of natural way and get
it kind of Falacci looking and I really liked that for the for the skull and
these spikes I wanted them to look like a
patinaed copper so I painted them out in like a brass paint first and then for
patina I just make my own mixed color which is it's a it's a green and an aqua
that I kind of mixed together till I get the right color and I just dabbed that
on to any kind of copper stuff I also did this statue out of a Disney toy from
the dollar store in a similar paint style you can kind of see the results a
little bit better on this perhaps maybe I'll do a video on this statue
specifically because really easy and it turned out pretty darn good but anyway
that's the way that I painted this sculpt
there's a lot more washes put on this so it kind of removed some of that but that
is my catacomb entrance alright guys I hope you found this video useful if you
did hit that like button and drop me a comment below and if you build something
inspired by one of my videos go over to the Blackmagic craft Facebook page and
post a picture if you haven't already subscribed hit that button and last if

new video equipment and software so that I can bring you better content and give
it to you more awesome I'll see you again next time peace
